metadata.synopsis: Updated recruitment dialogue for Gale, post-EA. Gale's arm appears from the waypoint teleporter near the nautiloid crash site. From the other side of the portal, he asks the player to grab his hand and pull him through. If they help, he can be recruited to the party, and will talk about seeing the players aboard the nautiloid.There is a Dark Urge moment in this dialogue, in which they can cut off Gale's arm before he is revelaed, killing him.

71.speaker: Gale
71.text: The currents of Weave around these sigils are absolutely fascinating. So much to explore!

136.speaker: Gale
136.text: A pity. I thought I sensed rapport, the promise of adventure, a flutter of excitement right here in my breadbasket... but perhaps it was merely indigestion.
136.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gestures towards his abdomen on 'here in my breadbasket'.NodeContext: Disappointed. Player has declined to take him along with them

102.speaker: Narrator
102.text: *You approach the sigil on the stone. Magic glitters and swirls from it erratically, as if malfunctioning. It looks slightly dangerous.*

156.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) You reach out to touch the sigil. When you touch it, sparks fly, and you quickly retract your hand in pain, like accidentally touching a red-hot pan.

46.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) Next, in the centre of the sparks, you suddenly see a hand and lower arm coming out of the sigil. The hand opens and closes, looking for something to hold on to. A voice resounds, or so it seems, from deep within the stone.

206.speaker: Player
206.text: Fantasise about hacking off the hand.

63.speaker: Narrator
63.text: *This branch of flesh is begging to be pruned, and its sap supped from.*
63.context: CinematicNodeContext: The Dark Urge goes into a spiral

144.speaker: Gale
144.text: By Mystra's eyelids, stop! Cease, you loon! Agh! Agh!
144.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player cannot see this.

12.speaker: Narrator
12.text: *As soon as the dreams cross the threshold of your imagination, you snap back to realise they have all come true.*
12.context: CinematicNodeContext: You see the stump of the arm is on the ground, bloody. A terrible cry of anguish is heard behind the waypoint as the magic sparkles and the sigil becomes dormant.

127.speaker: Lae'zel
127.text: Your lust for blood is rare. Let us hope you know where to direct it.

225.speaker: Astarion
225.text: Just full of surprises, aren't you?

67.speaker: Shadowheart
67.text: You were supposed to lend a hand, not take one.

158.speaker: Narrator
158.text: *Joy floods through you. You were dazed on the nautiloid. But now you are truly awake, alive.*

222.speaker: Wyll
222.text: Poor man! That's no way to treat a stranger in need.

219.speaker: Karlach
219.text: Whoa. What the fuck just happened?

121.speaker: Gale
121.text: Just your average traveller stuck between realms. Pull me out and we'll get properly introduced.

97.speaker: Gale
97.text: Ow! Perhaps I should have clarified. A helping hand? Anyone?

16.speaker: Gale
16.text: Harder! Come on, put your back into it!

181.speaker: Player
181.text: Pull again, as hard as you can.

10.speaker: Gale
10.text: That's it! Go on, keep pulling!

101.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) You pull with all your might, and slowly the upper arm starts to emerge from the sigil. Then suddenly Gale stumbles out from the stone, wobbling a bit before regaining his balance.

202.speaker: Gale
202.text: Ooft, hello. I'm Gale of Waterdeep. Apologies, I'm usually better at this.

218.speaker: Player
218.text: Careful! I kept calm before, but touching me could easily kill you.

95.speaker: Player
95.text: No need to apologise. Are you all right?

175.speaker: Gale
175.text: A bit shocked, but friend, it's a relief and a pleasure to make your acquaintance.

130.speaker: Gale
130.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale wistfully glances behind him at the waypoint, thinking on how close a scrape it was. Foreshaowing of him mourning his former magical skills.

153.speaker: Gale
153.text: Say, but I know you, don't I? In a manner of speaking. You were on the nautiloid as well.

170.speaker: Gale
170.text: Then I can only assume you too were on the receiving end of a rather unwelcome insertion in the ocular region.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: Never mind the nautiloid. How did you get stuck in that stone?

93.speaker: Gale
93.text: I don't know what transpired exactly, but the ship broke into pieces and I suddenly found myself in freefall.

2.speaker: Gale
2.text: As I was plummeting to certain death, I spied a glimmer quite near where I estimated my body to impact with less-than-savoury propulsion.

150.speaker: Gale
150.text: Recognising this glimmer to be magical in nature, I reached out to it with a Weaving of words and found myself on the other side as it were.

74.speaker: Gale
74.text: How about you? How did you survive the fall?

190.speaker: Player
190.text: To be honest, I haven't a clue.

55.speaker: Gale
55.text: Fair enough. But even so, I have the unfortunate suspicion your survival is still very much in jeopardy.

96.speaker: Player
96.text: I took control of the ship, landed it safely and saved the day.

151.speaker: Gale
151.text: That vast, burning wreckage behind you somewhat contradicts your story, but here you stand, so who am I to argue?

62.speaker: Gale
62.text: Still, swashbuckling heroics aside, I have the unfortunate suspicion your survival is still very much in jeopardy.

82.speaker: Player
82.text: I survived. That's all that matters.

42.speaker: Gale
42.text: I quite agree, but I have the unfortunate suspicion your survival is still very much in jeopardy.

197.speaker: Gale
197.text: Back on the ship, you too were on the receiving end of a rather unwelcome insertion in the ocular region, were you not?

159.speaker: Player
159.text: Couldn't have phrased it more repellently myself.

45.speaker: Gale
45.text: No use sugarcoating it, is there?

133.speaker: Player
133.text: That's hardly any of your business.

157.speaker: Gale
157.text: Gotcha. Private. Nothing to do with me.

88.speaker: Gale
88.text: And yet, if we indulge in the hypothetical for a moment...

72.speaker: Gale
72.text: As a githyanki, it's no news to you that this parasite will soon turn us into mind flayers - an outcome I'd rather like to avoid.

114.speaker: Gale
114.text: The insertee we speak of, this parasite - are you aware that after a period of excruciating gestation it will turn us into mind flayers?

162.speaker: Gale
162.text: It's a process known as ceremorphosis, and let me assure you: it is to be avoided.

155.speaker: Gale
155.text: So speaking about divine intervention, you don't happen to be a cleric, by any chance, do you? A doctor? Surgeon? Uncannily adroit with a knitting needle?

20.speaker: Gale
20.text: You don't happen to be a cleric, by any chance, do you? A doctor? Surgeon? Uncannily adroit with a knitting needle?

209.speaker: Shadowheart
209.text: You seem to know enough about our condition to realise it is beyond most clerics' skills.

198.speaker: Gale
198.text: Most, no doubt. But I find myself hoping to be in the presence of the few. You don't happen to be one of them?

1.speaker: Player
1.text: I was going to ask you the same question.

196.speaker: Gale
196.text: Then it looks like we're both starved for answers.

173.speaker: Player
173.text: I can knit you a cap, but that's where my prowess with the knitting needle stops.

58.speaker: Gale
58.text: A cap would keep the parasite nice and cosy, but its comfort is hardly my priority.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: These tadpoles are beyond even my arcane knowledge. I cannot remove them.

49.speaker: Gale
49.text: I suppose few enough can. It's not exactly a common affliction.

186.speaker: Gale
186.text: We're most certainly going to need a healer, and soon too. How about we lend each other a helping hand once more and look for a healer together?

200.speaker: Player
200.text: Sounds like a plan. You're welcome to join me.

191.speaker: Player
191.text: No, thank you. I'm not looking for another travelling companion.

76.speaker: Gale
76.text: Are you certain? There might be danger around the next corner, and a wizard is excellent company to keep.

124.speaker: Player
124.text: Fair enough. Yes, I'd like you to join me after all.

29.speaker: Gale
29.text: Most excellent. A parasite shared is a parasite halved. Or something to that effect.

90.speaker: Gale
90.text: Oh! But before you think you're about to embark on a journey with most ill-mannered a man: thank you for pulling me out of that stone.

53.speaker: Gale
53.text: It was an act of foresighted kindness I assure you, for I have the feeling ample opportunities will present themselves for me to return the favour.

25.speaker: Gale
25.text: Oh, but I see now you're travelling with plenty of company already. Perhaps I can join you later instead.

184.speaker: Gale
184.text: Oh, but I've just come to realise you're not the leader of this little troupe. My joining your ranks is not your call to make, I'm afraid.

115.speaker: Gale
115.text: Hail your party leader, would you? I'd like to join if deemed amenable.

213.speaker: Gale
213.text: Your quite significant loss. Farewell then, and good luck.

163.speaker: Gale
163.text: As we've established, few enough can. It's not exactly a common affliction.

128.speaker: Player
128.text: I attribute it to divine intervention.

87.speaker: Gale
87.text: It is a valuable commodity, to be favoured so by the gods.

142.speaker: Gale
142.text: But even so, I have the unfortunate suspicion your survival is still very much in jeopardy.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: You don't trust this man. Draw your weapon.

224.speaker: Gale
224.text: Whoa - easy does it. You really, really don't want to do that. Not a threat, just an observation.

154.speaker: Gale
154.text: Much obliged. Besides, I suspect the real villain here is one we have in common.

140.speaker: Player
140.text: And why would I really, really not want attack you?

122.speaker: Gale
122.text: Ten years of bad luck if you kill a wizard. Why take the risk?

34.speaker: Gale
34.text: Then you leave me no choice but to answer your folly with fury.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: At not wasting the time of passing adventurers? I certainly hope so.

212.speaker: Gale
212.text: Apologies, I didn't exactly memorise my cephalopodian banishment spells last night. Wasn't the best prepared for an attack-by-squid.

30.speaker: Gale
30.text: No! I'm slipping away! I'll perish in here!

99.speaker: Gale
99.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The hand disappears into the sparkles and the sigil becomes dormant. A cry of 'I'll perish!' echoes several times, sounding increasingly far away, like an echo. Then silence.

205.speaker: Player
205.text: This is more trouble than it's worth. Leave him to his fate.

227.speaker: Gale
227.text: No! I can't make it out by myself. I'll perish in here!

223.speaker: Gale
223.context: CinematicNodeContext: (Cine) The hand disappears into the sparkles and the sigil becomes dormant. A cry of 'I'll perish!' echoes several times, sounding increasingly far away, like an echo. Then silence.

195.speaker: Player
195.text: Whisper to the Weave roiling within the sigil. Attempt to calm it down.

50.speaker: Gale
50.text: Whatever you're doing, it's working wonders! Now a quick little pull should do the trick.

38.speaker: Narrator
38.text: *The magic around the sigil hisses like a cornered cat. Your only option now, is to grab the hand and pull.*

98.speaker: Player
98.text: Muster your strength and yank harder.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: It's far too dangerous. Leave him to his fate.

172.speaker: Player
172.text: Attune yourself to the sigil's magic, then bid it to quiet down.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: Let flow some words of prayer to soothe the sigil's magic.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: Let flow some words of prayer to soothe the sigil's magic.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: With a keen, but calculated twist, you attempt to sabotage the sigil.

129.speaker: Gale
129.text: Ah, my saviour! I'd be in quite a bind if not for your valiant tugging.
129.context: NodeContext: Warm/grateful. Follow-up greeting after the player managed to yank him out of a rock he was magically trapped in,

160.speaker: Gale
160.text: My, I hope it has been made abundantly clear that to kill me is... counterproductive.

80.speaker: Gale
80.text: I'd thank you for bringing me back to life, but your ending it in the first place has me rather in two minds about you.

84.speaker: Gale
84.text: That said, despite my return to the land of the living my predicament remains, and so of course does yours.

167.speaker: Gale
167.text: As such, I'm feeling magnanimous enough to let bygones be bygones. A healer is what we need. Shall we?

132.speaker: Gale
132.text: Most excellent! Then without further ado, let's be off!

134.speaker: Gale
134.text: Here's hoping we come across a powerful healer and a powerful wizard both.

138.speaker: Gale
138.text: I'd happily accept, but you're not the leader of your little troupe, are you? Not your call to make, I'm afraid.

78.speaker: Gale
78.text: And I'm flattered, I'm sure - but it seems you're travelling with a substantial amount of companions already. Maybe later, yes?

8.speaker: Player
8.text: All right. Meet me at camp.

100.speaker: Gale
100.text: I'll make my way to your camp, and embark upon a succulent slow-cook to be consumed upon your return.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: Take Astarion's place - he can head back to camp.

161.speaker: Narrator
161.text: *Your companion is otherwise engaged. You'll need to dismiss them at a more convenient moment.*

43.speaker: Astarion
43.text: I would object, but sitting by the fire while you do all the hard work sounds marvellous, actually.
43.context: NodeContext: Astarion speaking to the companion origin character that's replacing him in the party. "Them" refers to the player's avatar characer.

5.speaker: Karlach
5.context: NodeContext: A bit immature bad attitude. Player has told her to swap with someone else who wants to join the party.

126.speaker: Gale
126.text: A decision most excellently made. Shall we?

210.speaker: Shadowheart
210.text: If you insist. Don't have all the fun without me.

221.speaker: Player
221.text: You can trade places with Wyll.

166.speaker: Wyll
166.text: All right. I know a shortcut.

24.speaker: Gale
24.text: You've grown none the wiser, I see.

164.speaker: Gale
164.text: I sense the leadership of your troupe lies elsewhere. I'd be most grateful for an introduction.

176.speaker: Gale
176.text: The currents of Weave around these sigils are absolutely fascinating. So much to explore!

211.speaker: Gale
211.text: Exploration merits companionship though. Shall we?
